question: In which league does Tre Evans play?

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Tre Evans Takes the Court in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

In a thrilling development for college basketball enthusiasts, Tre Evans has officially joined the ranks of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. As a talented player, Evans has brought his skills to the forefront, representing Fordham University in the 2018 season. According to NCAA records, Tre Evans was a member of the Fordham Rams men's basketball team during the 2018 season, solidifying his position in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. This prestigious league is comprised of the top college basketball programs in the United States, featuring powerhouse teams like Duke, Kentucky, and North Carolina. "Tre Evans was an integral part of our team during the 2018 season," said Jeff Neubauer, Fordham University's head men's basketball coach. "His dedication and passion for the game were evident in every practice and every game. We're proud to have had him represent Fordham in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league." Data from the NCAA reveals that Fordham University is one of the 358 institutions that participate in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. As a member of this elite group, Evans had the opportunity to compete against the best of the best in college basketball. "Playing in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is an incredible experience," said Evans in an exclusive interview. "The level of competition is unmatched, and it pushes you to be your best every time you step onto the court. I'm grateful to have had the chance to be a part of it." The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is renowned for its rich history, dating back to 1939. With a total of 32 conferences and over 4,800 student-athletes, it is the pinnacle of college basketball competition. "Tre Evans' participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a testament to his hard work and commitment to the sport," said Dan Gavitt, NCAA Senior Vice President of Basketball. "We're proud to have him as part of the NCAA family and look forward to seeing his continued success on and off the court." In conclusion, the evidence is clear: Tre Evans is a talented college basketball player who has had the privilege of competing in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. With his skills and dedication, he is sure to make a lasting impact on the world of college basketball.
content.source_2: As the sun dipped below the Helsinki horizon, casting a warm orange glow over the frozen landscape, Tre Evans laced up his skates in the dimly lit locker room of the Espoo Eagles. It was a far cry from the bright lights of Fordham University's Rose Hill Gym, where he had once sunk three-pointers with ease as a college basketball player. But life had taken an unexpected turn, and Tre found himself trading in his sneakers for skates, his jump shot for a slapshot. The Eagles' coach, a gruff but kind-hearted Finn named Jukka, patted Tre on the back as he made his way to the ice. "You're doing great, Amerikka," he said, using the nickname that had stuck since Tre's arrival in Finland. "You've got the heart of a lion, even if your hockey skills are still a work in progress." Tre smiled, feeling a sense of belonging he hadn't experienced since leaving the States. It wasn't easy, of course – the language barrier, the unfamiliarity with the Finnish game, the endless cups of coffee to stay warm in the subzero temperatures. But there was something about the camaraderie of the team, the thrill of competition, that had drawn him in. As he took to the ice, the crowd of a few hundred fans cheered and chanted his name. Tre Evans, the American import, was still a novelty in the Jääkiekon III-divisioona league, but he was quickly becoming a fan favorite. His speed and agility, honed on the basketball court, served him well on the ice, and his determination to learn had earned him the respect of his teammates. As the game got underway, Tre's mind wandered back to the States, to the friends and family who had thought he was crazy to leave behind the comforts of college basketball for the unknown of Finnish hockey. But as he swooped in to intercept a pass, his stickhandling skills still a bit rough but improving with every game, he knew he had made the right decision.
